title: BHP in Mexican oil for the long haul, despite wave of nationalism
text:
Speaking in Houston on Thursday, BHP's petroleum boss Geraldine Slattery said she had been re-assured by the first ten months of AMLO's reign.

''At a fundamental level, despite the change in rhetoric and administration, we have been very re-assured with the continued support for the sanctity of contracts in Mexico,'' she said.

''We see that the objectives of the administration are very tied to our own in terms of exploiting the resource for the benefit of not just the Mexican economy, but supporting improvements socially, and that is very much tied to how we like to operate as a company, and so we are advancing our plans there.

''We do continue to look at growth opportunities and we are quite optimistic actually that Mexico will play out over the long term.''

The first four holes drilled in Trion encountered hydrocarbons, and in a positive sign, the resource is estimated to be mostly fluids rather than gas.

In August Goldman Sachs valued BHP's 60 per cent stake in Trion at $US1.8 billion, and estimates the field could start producing oil in 2025, with peak production in 2027.

In an interview with Bloomberg in July, AMLO said auctions to the private sector could be resumed “if they produce and comply''.

Advertisement

BHP is one of very few companies that straddle both mining and oil and gas, and petroleum's place in the portfolio was challenged by Elliott Management in 2017, with the activist investor suggesting the division should be demerged.

The push came at a time when Elliott was quietly looking to buy US domiciled oil and gas assets, including through a "blank cheque'' acquisition vehicle called Vantage Energy Acquisition Corporation.

Elliott has also considered buying the shale assets of US listed company QEP Resources, in which it is a shareholder, and which ironically boasts former BHP petroleum boss Tim Cutt as its chief executive.

Ms Slattery said on Thursday that petroleum was set to remain part of BHP as it provided the company with valuable diversification.

''We look to be in commodities with attractive demand trajectories and ability to generate rent, which are big assets that have growth potential, and we seek to do those things that we have capabilities in – we are good at them,'' she said.

''So when you put petroleum in that context then not only are we an integral part of the portfolio, but in fact we are a growth pillar, along with copper and that’s fundamentally because we believe in the demand trajectory, particularly for oil, and also for gas, and we think we have got the capabilities to generate returns from that.

''So I think we are here to stay and as long as we see the attraction in oil and gas commodities, I think you will find that’s the case.''
description: BHP believes it can still build a long-term oil business in Mexico despite the protectionist streak of the nation's new president.
